description_html:
This gallery contains images of the personalities of some of the wildlings who live north of The Wall in the show Game of Thrones. Click on one of the images on this page to see a full-sized image on its own page.

GoT: The Big Picture

There are dozens of characters in Game of Thrones. Sadly, this site cannot do justice to the vast number of relationships in the show because it is designed for presenting individual images.

Fortunately there are two Visualizing Game of Thrones Personalities books available. To learn more about these books, click on SEE THE STORY!
story_html:
The large number of characters on Game of Thrones gives fans of the show the opportunity to see patterns in personalities. For example, out of 42 characters, I found 10 ESTJs and 8 ISTJs, but only 1 ENFJ (Melisandre) and 1 INFJ (Daenerys). Hmmm, interesting!

Two editions of the book Visualizing Game of Thrones Personalities (VGoTP) are available:

  • VGoTP Mini-ebook Edition — less content and best for phones, 89 pages
  • VGoTP Full Edition: From Ned and Cersei to Tyrion and Daenerys — best for larger screens, 171 pages

Both books begin with a chapter looking at each of the Houses, then go on to include a chapter that compares and contrasts both similar and dissimlar Pairs of people. Following that is a chapter examining Groups of similar personalities, and both editions also include a Character Index and a list of Characters and Their Types at the end.

Additionally, the Full Edition includes an extra chapter offering Insights into some patterns of relationships. Ultimately the Full Edition includes close to twice as much information as the Mini-ebook Edition.

Click one of the links above to get your Visualizing Game of Thrones Personalities book today!

image_list.title: Ygritte
image_list.subtitle_html: Jon Snow's Wildling Lover
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Ygritte's spiritual portrait shows she is realistic and can remain cool and calm when threatened.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in Ygritte's spiritual portrait represents her dominant personality trait, her moderate preference for being more objective than subjective.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  She demonstrated this preference in the way she murdered citizens in cold blood during raids in the north of Westeros.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in Ygritte's spiritual portrait represents her auxiliary personality trait, her strong preference for being realistic.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.

image_list.title: Tormund Giantsbane
image_list.subtitle_html: Wildling Leader and Ally of Jon Snow
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Tormund's spiritual portrait shows he is cool, objective, and realistic.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in Tormund's spiritual portrait represents his dominant personality trait, his tendency to be more objective than emotional.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  Tormund exhibits this tendency when he is taken prisoner by the Nights Watch after the wildling's raid on Castle Black, when he shows no emotion at the prospect of being put to death, and seems interested only in the method.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in Tormund's spiritual portrait represents his auxiliary personality trait, his strong tendency to see the world more in terms of facts rather than ideas.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  Tormund exhibits this tendency rather comically in a war room with Jon Snow, when Jon expresses concern about their army being caught in a pincer move.  Tormund does not react to the term, so Jon explains it in simpler terms.  Hearing that he wants to prevent being attacked from the sides, Tormund finally elicits a single word in response, 'good,' so Jon knows he got through to him the second time.

image_list.title: Gilly
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Gilly's spiritual portrait shows she is warm and friendly, realistic but also reticent.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in Gilly's spiritual portrait represents her dominant personality trait, her warmth and friendliness.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  Gilly shows this preference in the way she quickly befriends Samwell and decides to save her baby's life by leaving Craster's Keep with him.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in Gilly's spiritual portrait represents her auxiliary personality trait, her realism and tendency to care more about facts than ideas.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  Although Gilly learns to read and shows some interest in Sam's work, she shows more concern about practical matters in general and taking care of her child in particular.
